segments.text: Only when she took the final steps to the door did she see the note attached to it and feel a sigh escape her lungs.
No matter what the wording would be this time, Josef wasn't home.
He was probably on one of his trips, likely in Tel Aviv.
The paradox was that she had just come from there.
I'll be back on Monday," he wrote this time.
As she pushed the door open, she saw a cup here, a plate there, an uncleaned ashtray, and the flowers she had placed last week in small vases, still in their yellowish, wilted water.
Suddenly she felt anger begin to bubble up inside her.
She removed her shoes at the entrance to the kitchen.

took off her shorts and tank top, braided her hair, feeling the anger that flared within her turn instantly into frantic activity, gathering the dishes to the sink, throwing out the wilted flowers, emptying the ashtrays, collecting the tablecloths, and soaking them in soapy water in the large outdoor sink.
Every step she took was accompanied by that anger growing stronger.
Why had she suddenly started getting angry?
She had always been so forgiving of him, making up excuses for him to the world, turning it into half a joke.
Like she told her friend Danny, there's no point in getting angry at him.
He's like a child looking for candy.
Even with the incident with Julie, the cleaning lady, when it became clear he rented rooms by the hour to shady characters.
After he slapped her when she spoke to him bluntly, even then it ended in a hug and forgiveness as she tried to comfort him, finding herself saying, it'll be okay, daddy.
So what the hell went wrong in just one year?
She was 17, he was 47.
A handsome, smart, intelligent, so talented man, an artist at heart, a speaker of languages, well liked by people, and he had quite a few good friends he'd gathered at each station of his life.
and she loved him so much.
He was her charming and unique daddy.
Apart from that one slap, all she had ever received from him were warm hugs, the kind that pull you into the heart.
Something had died in him on one hand and became defiant on the other.
and he was searching for his way, realizing that the known path was disappearing and would soon be gone.

But like this, he had lost all desire to do, let the days drag him along, waiting for them to end, and starting the next day with almost complete indifference, as if the knowledge that he was about to lose the work of his life
everything in which he had invested his all, his energy, the place Lucy had given her everything to, and ultimately her soul.
This thing that would soon be gone had stopped all the wheels of activity in him.
Every morning when he entered the dining room, he would gaze at his paintings hung on the surrounding walls.
It was a constant testimony to his talent, even without being defined professionally as a painter.
It allowed him to share his paintings with those many people who passed through the pink house and seemingly received their approval and appreciation.
He always paused at Lucy's portrait, feeling the vast void of her absence.

he had always been a man of action, from the days of the brigade through the command at Telowinsky before it became Telhashomer, the move to the Mossad and later the founding of the first hotel in Ashkelon.

And now he was like a sick man, entirely focused on himself, on his grief and his anger at the injustice, seeking escape in the big city, flirting with everyone, disappearing for days without considering the handful of guests or his daughter who had just turned 17.
For him, she was already an adult.
Suddenly, she was the one worrying about him, cleaning, organizing, watering her mother's garden, clinging into his place in this beautiful house, which was also dying as if it too were sick.
She didn't bother him as if waiting patiently for the storm to pass.
Maybe in the end, it'll be okay after all.

Despite this, in the house he painted pink, who gave in its name and also colored her life with much optimism, the skies turned gray for him, and he became entirely shrouded in gray, not believing he could manage what would come next, unsure he was.
Built to start everything from scratch, there were things she saw at certain moments in her mind as if she were reliving pictures that remained within the aperture of her memory.
Joseph sitting on the high bar chair, a beer in hand, watching the dining room full of guests, making sure everything ticks as he put it.
Or Joseph standing by his easel, taking a step back, observing with concentration, then reaching a confident hand and boldly sketching along it, forgetting all around him.
In winter, the house would switch to a slow pace.
no longer dozens of vacationers to tend to from morning to night, then suddenly there was time for spiritual pursuits.

Joseph would take out the old easel from the storage room, place it at the end of the dining room, facing the large glass doors, open his paint suitcase, prepare brushes of various sizes, clean the spatula for oil paints.
Soften his watercolor brushes with a massage between his fingers and bring to large sheets those sketches he had drawn for himself throughout the year in his portable sketch pad.
The sea and skies were always blue in countless shades of blue.
You could almost perceive his mood from the shade he painted them.
Sometimes stormy, dark, almost somber, and sometimes bright.
Most landscapes were painted in watercolor.
Only in a few paintings did he focus on oils.
Spread with special brushes and applied with the spatula, forming some kind of ridges on the painting.
A precious light would penetrate the balcony through the glass doors, and by afternoon, when the sun began to set, the light would change completely.
That's how he loved it.
He also loved her sitting at his feet.
It didn't bother him at all.
On the contrary, she gives me inspiration, he would say to Lucy.

And so, while he was busy painting, she would be sprawled at his feet, sometimes even Kim the dog, finding her own occupations around his standing place and savoring their togetherness while each was engrossed in their activity.
All walls of the dining room were strewn with his paintings.
Almost in every visible corner hung a picture.
He would throw his finished sheets on the floor after they dried and Lucy would sort through them for the best and ensure the framer came to their house.
She would choose the appropriate frame for each picture and once the work was complete she would find the right spot for it based on its color and essence.
She also decorated the guest rooms with his paintings.
When he painted, he would forget his cigarette at the edge of his mouth, and it would burn out slowly, the ash falling and scattering around him without him even noticing.
He would light one cigarette from the other and not even smoke them.
merely holding them between his lips, letting them burn out on their own.
Lucy would laugh and say that when Yosef finished painting, the colors were the easy part of the cleaning.
The main mess was the cigarette ash around.

She loved watching him paint and would peek at him from a distance while engaged in her activities, thinking there was something warm and touching about her handsome man standing and painting with his little daughter at his feet.
something that casts tranquility upon him and her as well.
God, what wouldn't she give for Lucy to return?
Take the reins in hand and bring some order both at home and in spirit.
If only he could see her for a moment, he would undoubtedly calm down.
Knowing she would find solutions, organize matters, and everything would come to a peaceful resolution.
Just come back for a moment to return her childhood, her youth, without having to take on responsibility.
Just like all her friends, how did she leave her like this and leave her to be the responsible adult?
She didn't want to raise a father.
She was just as anxious about what would happen.
No less than he was.
She just repressed and hit it.

She beautified every murky thought that surfaced, coloring it in her pink and oddly stepped into Lucy's shoes, trying to impose some order and organization, leaving the pink house clean and decorated as it was.
For the few people who still pass through, and mainly for herself, deep inside, she knew not everything was as it should be.
It's not enough to just paint everything pink, past the days in the routine actions of doing the same tasks.

Essentially sketching her daily routine, passing one day after the next, forming the walls of repression against those deep emotions that sought to erupt, the loneliness, the loneliness and the longing, belonging for what was, for the magical childhood, for the sense of security and happiness and the great freedom in which she grew and thrived, the longing for the mother who would not return, the longing for the father as he was before.
and the pain of knowing it would never be the same again.
Sometimes she had moments of deep understanding that something in all that was happening wasn't entirely normal.
Still, amid all the mix of feelings, she almost felt no fear.
It wasn't fear of what would come.
It was mainly the strong desire to ensure things would be good, that they would be different.
With each passing day, she understood more and more the phrase, if I am not for myself, who will be for me?

realizing that her fate was in her own hands, that soon she would have to earn a living, defer dreams of education and higher learning, and try to gain wisdom from the endless books she read, slowly becoming autodidactic.
Deep inside, she took comfort knowing life was equipping her with skills none of her friends could ever learn at any university.
There are things people learn firsthand, and they are the most essential doctorate one will ever earn, a doctorate in the sciences of life.
